description: No singers
name: NoSinger

description: One solo singer, whether or not accompanied by instruments.
name: SoloSinger

description: One singer with an audience whose dancing, shouting, etc. can be heard. In practice we omitted this point and coded all solos .
name: SoloSingerAudience

description: Two or more singers alternate in singing a melody, or split the melody between them in some way. Only one singer is heard at a time.
name: SoloSingerConsecutive

description: A single predominant voice—a leader— stands out above the general effect of social unison. The leader’s voice is usually louder and more forceful than the others. Sometimes the leader imitates phrases or other parts of the melody. Sometimes the leader seems to spur the group on. In general, a predominant part is louder, more elaborate, more active, or longer than the others.
name: UnisonPredominantLeader

description: No predominant lead voice is steadily heard over the social unison. Sometimes a leader can be heard briefly above the group at beginnings of sections, but as soon as the group joins in, the leader’s voice is submerged.
name: SocialUnisonPredominantGroup

description: A diffuse, individualized group performance is rhythmically and/or melodically diffuse, such that in extreme cases the singers do not seem to be aware of one another at all.
name: DiffuseGroup

description: Situations in which there is alternation between a solo voice and a chorus with a perceptible, if sometimes very slight, pause between the two parts.
name: LeaderGroup

description: Two groups of two or more singers interact as described for 7, above. The same rules for double coding apply.
name: GroupGroup

description: A more integrated alternation of leader and chorus, whose parts overlap so that one begins before the other ends. In extreme cases the chorus may also be heard backing the leader during his or her own part. However, the leader is still predominant; his or her part is longer than that of the group and often more elaborate. The group’s activity supports and contrasts with the leader’s part.
name: LeaderGroupOverlap

description: This is the same as 10, except that the group predominates rather than the leader. Although it may sometimes support the leader, the group is very active, and sings more than half of the time.
name: GroupLeaderOverlapAlternation

description: Two or more groups overlap as in 10. In those rare cases where the groups are radically different in size (for example, two singers versus 20), 12 is still coded, even though the smaller group may give the impression of leading the larger.
name: GroupGroupOverlapAlternation

description: A group in which several voices overlap in a rhythmically coordinated relationship. Often there is no clear leading part; all seem about equally important. Although some singers may be duplicating another part at the octave or in unison, the general impression is of a group of individuals, each with his or her own part, interacting in such a way as to create a homogeneous texture.
name: Interlock

description: No accompaniment.
name: NonOccurence

description: A small orchestra (1-3 players) accompanying the vocal part and subordinate to it. One or more of the instruments may perform the melody.
name: SmallOrchestra

description: A large orchestra (4+ players) in the same relationship as 2.
name: LargeOrchestra

description: A large or small orchestra predominant over the sung part. The orchestra’s part takes up more time and/or is considerably louder than the sung part.
name: OrchestraOverSong

description: The orchestra (large or small) plays interludes between passages. It is never heard simultaneously with the vocal part.
name: OrchestraBetweenInterludes

description: A small orchestra (1-3 players) that seems unrelated or only casually related to the vocal part. The effect resembles that described under 7 (ind. group) on Line 1, and is the result, usually, of some absence of rhythmic coordination between instruments and voices.
name: SmallOrchestraUnrelatedVocal

description: A large orchestra (4+ players) that seems unrelated or only casually related to the vocal part.
name: LargeOrchestraUnrelatedVocal

description: A small orchestra (1-3 players) in complementary relationship to singer(s). The instruments are basically coordinated with and subordinate to the vocal part, but provide more than a mere background for the voices, as in 2 (small orch) and 3 (large orch).
name: SmallOrchestraRelatedVocal

description: A large orchestra (4+ players) in complementary relationship to singer(s).
name: LargeOrchestraRelatedVocal

description: Non-occurrence. No instruments.
name: NonOccurence

description: One solo instrument. An accompaniment or a solo on one instrument.
name: SoloInstrument

description: Series of solos. One instrumental solo after another.
name: SoloSeries

description: Social unison with leader predominant. Other instruments are subordinate to the leader, playing the same tune in the same way or in simple accompanying parts.
name: UnisonPredominantLeader

description: Social unison with no predominant instrument. Unison performances in which no single instrument takes the lead, and performances in which there is a simple accompanying relationship between the leading instrument and the other instrument(s).
name: SocialUnisonNoPredominantInstrument

description: Diffuse/individualized relationship, leader predominant. Similar to 7 (ind./var. group) in Line 1, but applied to the relationships among the instruments of the orchestra. Single lead instrument is predominant.
name: DiffuseLeaderPredominant

description: Diffuse/individualized relationship, group predominant. Similar to 7 (ind./var. group) in Line 1, but applied to the relationships among the instruments of the orchestra. Either the leader is subordinate to the group or leadership shifts from one instrument to another.
name: DiffuseGroupPredominant

description: Simple alternation: leader-group. A simple antiphonal relationship between a single lead instrument and an orchestra (see 8 Line 1 alt. ldr-grp).
name: LeaderGroupAlternation

description: Simple alternation: group-group. An orchestra divided into two or more parts with an antiphonal relationship between them.
name: GroupGroupAlternation

description: Overlapping alternation: leader-group. Alternation between a single instrument and a group, but with overlap (see 10, Line 1 overlap: ldr-grp).
name: LeaderGroupOverlapAlternation

description: Overlapping alternation: group-leader. Alternation between a single instrument and a group with no one instrument in the foreground more often than the others.
name: GroupLeaderOverlapAlternation

description: Overlapping alternation: group-group. The orchestra is divided into two or more groups, each of which acts as a unit, with significant overlap between them, or in an interlocking relationship, as described in Line 1 (13).
name: GroupGroupOverlapAlternation

description: Two or more singers who are totally unrelated musically. Each singer has their own part and goes their own way, although they sing simultaneously.
name: Unrelated

description: Monophony. Only one voice is heard at a time.
name: Monophony

description: Unison. Two or more voices singing at the same melody in unison or octaves, and conforming to the same rhythmic pattern.
name: Unison

description: Heterophony. Each voice sings the same melody in a slightly different manner. The variation is usually rhythmic, with some voices trailing behind, others pushing forward, or with some voices more rhythmically active than others.
name: Heterophony

description: Polyphony. The use of simultaneously produced intervals other than unison or the octave. (Line 22 gives six categories of polyphony.) Two-part intervals of this kind are considered polyphony, as well as harmonies of greater complexity.
name: Polyphony

description: Solo
name: Solo

description: Minimal Blend (Very individualized). Singers do not attempt to match one another in tone. Individual voices stand out, and the effect can be strident or tumultuous, often producing a rich and interesting texture.
name: MinimalBlend

description: Medium Blend (Rather individualized). Some tonal matching occurs, but individual voices may still be heard.
name: MediumBlend

description: Significant Blend (Unified blend). The group sounds resonant as a whole, with some stridence.
name: SignificantBlend

description: Maximal blend. The singers match one another’s tone in such a way as to present the effect of a single tone quality. Any stridency is the result of harmonic dissonance rather than blend. The total effect is highly resonant, clear, and unified.
name: MaximalBlend

description: Solo
name: Solo

description: Minimal rhythmic coordination. An individualized, rhythmically asynchronous performance.
name: MinimalCoordination

description: Moderate rhythmic coordination. Some degree of rhythmic coordination, still considerably individualized.
name: ModerateCoordination

description: Unified rhythmic coordination. Attacks and releases are generally coordinated but not precisely so.
name: UnifiedCoordination

description: Maximal rhythmic coordination. Precise coordination at every rhythmic level.
name: MaximalCoordination

description: Non-occurrence. No instruments or Two or more instruments perceived to be totally asynchronous.
name: NonOccurence

description: Monophony. One instrument playing one note at a time, or in octaves.
name: Monophony

description: Unison. A group of instruments playing the same melody in unison or in octaves, an instrumental solo with simple percussion accompaniment—drum, rattle, sticks, clapping, etc., or any untuned percussion ensemble unless playing in polyrhythm, in which case, code 13 (Polyrhythm) (see Point 5).

Heterophony. Each instrument plays the same melody in a slightly different manner. The variation is usually rhythmic, with some instruments trailing behind, others pushing forward; or with some instruments more rhythmically active than others.
name: Heterophony

description: Polyphony or polyrhythm. The use of simultaneously produced intervals other than unison or the octave. Two-part intervals of this kind are considered polyphony, as well as harmonies of greater complexity.
name: PolyphonyPolyrhythm

description: Non-occurrence. No group. Only one instrument in the ensemble, or no instruments at all.
name: NonOccurence

description: Minimal blend. Little or no overall sonority. Instruments contrast in tone quality and do not reinforce one another at all.
name: MinimalBlend

description: Medium blend.
name: MediumBlend

description: Significant Blend.
name: SignificantBlend

description: Maximal blend. Total effect is highly sonorous.
name: MaximalBlend

description: Non-occurrence. No instruments, or no ensemble—one instrument only.
name: NonOccurence

description: Minimal rhythmic coordination. The members of a group share a rhythmic pattern that is so individualized that the effect is extremely asynchronous.
name: MinimalCoordination

description: Moderate rhythmic coordination. A group that plays together on the beat, or follows the same rhythmic pattern or patterns, in a cohesive fashion.
name: ModerateCoordination

description: Unified rhythmic coordination. There is clear-cut coordination of attack and release on the beat.
name: UnifiedCoordination

description: Maximal or highly unified rhythmic coordination. The orchestra is tightly linked together rhythmically.
name: MaximalCoordination

description: Little or no repetition—wordy. A continuous stream of dissimilar sung syllables, words, and phrases, with little or no repetition or use of non-lexical utterances. In such songs—epics, ballads, songs of prayer and supplication, and much of Western and Eurasian song—text is of paramount importance.
name: LittleRepetition

description: Some repetition. Some repetition and/or the use of non-lexical utterances—about one fourth repeated text.
name: SomeRepetition

description: Half repetition. A substantial amount of repetition and/or non-lexical utterances that more or less equals the flow of unrepeated words.
name: HalfRepetition

description: Quite repetitious. Considerably more than half (about two-thirds) of the sung performance is accounted for by repetition and/or non-lexical utterances.
name: QuiteRepetitious

description: Extreme repetition. The text seems to be almost entirely composed of repetition of some kind and/or non-lexical utterances.
name: ExtremeRepetition

description: Non-occurrence. No singers.
name: NonOccurence

description: One-beat rhythm. A series of equally accented single notes of about the same length.
name: OneBeat

description: Simple meter. One simple meter—duple, triple, “simple,” or compound—runs through the whole song.
name: SimpleMeter

description: Complex meter. Here, as with 6 (simple meter), one meter prevails throughout the song. In 9, however, the measure cannot be evenly divided by two or three to form subunits of two or three beats each.
name: ComplexMeter

description: Irregular meter. No single meter prevails throughout.
name: IrregularMeter

description: Parlando rubato. Free rhythm, in which no regularly recurring beat can be distinguished, is often close to speech in general effect. Accents and rhythmic patterns are grouped in meaningful ways, but without reference to a regular division of time into steady beats.
name: ParlandoRubato

description: Non-patterned. No rhythmic coherence of any sort. Each individual is independent and does not relate rhythmically to the others. Also, a solo singer.
name: NonPatterened

description: Rhythmic unison. All voices move together with little or no rhythmic independence. A group may sing in parts and still be in rhythmic unison. All parts follow basically the same rhythm, so that they move together note for note.
name: RhythmicUnison

description: Rhythmic heterophony. The singers tend to follow the same rhythmic pattern but one or more singers consistently deviates from the others in some way. Some may be out of phase with and trail the others; some may embellish the melody in an individual manner, or use more or less rubato than the others. They may follow the rhythm in a general way, trailing and catching up between the notes.
name: RhythmicHeterophony

description: Accompanying rhythm. The singing group is divided into two or more parts, one of which accompanies the other. The accompanying part has independent rhythmic patterns but these are subordinate to the main part.
name: AccompanyingRhythm

description: Simple polyrhythm. All of the parts basically conform to a single pulse. However, there are moments when one of the parts will temporarily deviate from the basic pulse to create a new pulse in conflict with it.
name: SimplePolyrhythm

description: Complex polyrhythm. Two or more conflicting pulses are heard simultaneously and more or less continuously throughout the song. (For a fuller explanation of 9 and 11, see explanatory note below.)
name: ComplexPolyrhythm

description: Rhythmic counterpoint. Two or more rhythmic patterns, equal to and distinct from one another, occur simultaneously within the same rhythmic framework, but without conflict of pulse.
name: RhythmicCounterpoint

description: Non-occurrence. No instruments
name: NonOccurence

description: One-beat rhythm. A series of equally accented single notes of about the same length.
name: OneBeat

description: Simple meter. One simple meter (duple, triple, simple, or compound) runs through the whole piece.
name: SimpleMeter

description: Complex meter. Here, as with 6, one meter prevails throughout the piece, however the measure cannot be evenly divided by two or three to form subunits of two or three beats each.
name: ComplexMeter

description: Irregular meter. No one meter prevails throughout. A piece that is basically in 3/4, but has one or more measures in 2/4, is coded 11, as well as a piece in which the meter shifts continually from measure to measure—for example, 3/4, 2/4, 3/4, 3/4, 5/4, 3/2, etc.
name: IrregularMeter

description: Parlando rubato. Free rhythm in which no regularly recurring beat can be distinguished.
name: ParlandoRubato

description: No orchestra or non-patterned.
name: NoOrchestra

description: Rhythmic unison. All instruments move together with little or no rhythmic independence. A group may play in parts and still be in rhythmic unison.
name: RhythmicUnison

description: Rhythmic heterophony. The instruments tend to follow the same rhythmic pattern, but one or more instruments consistently deviates from the others in some way. Some may be out of phase with and trail the others. Some may embellish the melody in an individual manner, or use more or less rubato (divergence from the strict beat) than others.
name: RhythmicHeterophony

description: Accompanying rhythm. The instrumental group is divided into two or more parts, one of which accompanies the other. The accompanying part has independent rhythmic patterns, but these are subordinate to the main part. They may be (1) less active rhythmically, (2) less active melodically, (3) softer, or (4) they may occur intermittently. If the accompanying part is equal in importance and rhythmic activity to the main part, so that the accompaniment becomes, in effect, another melody, consider coding 13 (Rc).
name: AccompanyingRhythm

description: Simple polyrhythm. All of the parts basically conform to a single pulse. However, there are moments when one of the parts will temporarily deviate from the basic pulse to create a new pulse in conflict with it. The conflict may last a moment or it may resolve itself only after several “measures,” as in much classical Indian music. In any case, this rhythmic conflict must be only temporary.
name: SimplePolyrhythm

description: Complex polyrhythm. Two or more conflicting pulses are heard simultaneously and more or less continually throughout the song.
name: ComplexPolyrhythm

description: Rhythmic counterpoint. Two or more rhythmic patterns, equal to and distinct from one another, occur simultaneously within the same rhythmic framework but without conflict of pulse. A fugue is an example of this quality, which is also vigorous in folk and indigenous music. The principal feature to watch for is the presence of two or more independent parts active throughout the piece.
name: RhythmicCounterpoint

description: Arched. An arched phrase begins at a certain point, rises in pitch, and then descends. Code at this point only if arched phrases occur prominently, not if the melody as a whole is arched.
name: Arched

description: Terraced. The entire melody is characterized by a long descent in pitch, interrupted by periods of leveling off and, in some cases, by incidental rises. The melody begins at a relatively high pitch, moves downward through a phrase or two, and then levels off. The next portion begins at the same pitch level or slightly above it, descending to an even lower point, where it once again levels off. This cascading descent proceeds throughout the song, so that the melody ends on or near its lowest point. A sketch of this kind of melody would resemble a terraced field or a tiled roof.
name: Terraced

description: Undulating. Most phrases have a wave-like shape. They move up and down through a number of peaks and valleys of varying heights. Also coded here are those rare cases in which the shape of the phrase is predominantly ascending.
name: Undulating

description: Descending. Most phrases descend gradually or abruptly.
name: Descending

description: Through-composed. A song that has no recognizable litany or strophic pattern, but instead is made up of a series of phrase groups in which consistently repeated sections seldom if ever occur. Not every section of the piece need consist of completely new material; certain melodic motifs may recur throughout, but not in a regularly occurring order. 1 is common in much Asian music as well as in Western art music.
name: ThroughComposed

description: Complex strophe with moderate to great variation.
name: ComplexStropheModerateVariation

description: Complex strophe with little or no variation. 3 is similar to, but more complex than, 6. More is contained within the form than the regular repetition of three to eight phrases.
name: ComplexStropheLittleVariation

description: Simple strophe with much variation.
name: SimpleStropheMuchVariation

description: Simple strophe with a moderate amount of variation.
name: SimpleStropheModerateVariation

description: Simple strophe with little or no variation. A series of three to eight (but not more than eight) phrases which are repeated, phrase by phrase, over and over, with no insertions of new material and no omissions or changes of order.
name: SimpleStropheLittleVariation

description: Complex litany with a high degree of variation in each section.
name: ComplexLitanyHighVariation

description: Complex litany with a moderate degree of variation in each section.
name: ComplexLitanyModerateVariation

description: Complex litany is similar to 12 (simple litany), but involves certain complications. Refer to guide
name: ComplexLitanyComplexVariation

description: Simple litany with a high degree of variation in each repeat.
name: SimpleLitanyHighVariation

description: Simple litany with a moderate amount of variation in each repeat.
name: SimpleLitanyModerateVariation

description: Simple litany. One or two phrases repeated over and over again in the same order with little or no variation: A A A A or AB AB AB AB. Code here even when such a form is preceded by one or two phrases of introduction.
name: SimpleLitany

description: Canonic or round form. Found only in certain types of polyphonic singing. The music is divided into two or more parts, each of which is rhythmically distinct. Each part is limited to one or two phrases repeated over and over. Simple rounds or canons are included here, and also the hocketing “bell chime” singing common among African Khoisan-speaking Bushmen and hunter-gatherers of Central and Eastern Africa.
name: CanonicForm

description: Very long phrases. Phrases that seem to run to the limit or beyond the limit of a singer’s breath capacity (16+ seconds).
name: VeryLongPhrases

description: Long phrases. An intermediate point between medium phrase lengths and very long phrases (10-15 seconds).
name: LongPhrases

description: Medium phrases. Normal for the familiar English ballad type (5-9 seconds).
name: MediumPhrases

description: Short phrases. (3-4 seconds).
name: ShortPhrases

description: Very short phrases. (1-2 seconds).
name: VeryShortPhrases

description: There are more than eight phrases before a full repeat.
name: MoreThanEightPhrases

description: There are five or seven phrases before a full repeat.
name: FiveSevenPhrases

description: There are four or eight phrases, asymmetrically arranged.
name: FourEightPhrasesAsymmetrical

description: Four or eight phrases symmetrically arranged. All phrases are approximately the same length.
name: FourEightPhrasesSymmerical

description: Three or six phrases, asymmetrically arranged.
name: ThreeSixPhrasesAsymmetrical

description: Three or six phrases, symmetrically arranged.
name: ThreeSixPhrasesSymmetrical

description: Two phrases asymmetrically arranged.
name: TwoPhrasesAsymmetrical

description: One or two phrases, symmetrically arranged.
name: OneTwoPhrasesSymmetrical

description: The final tone is the lowest note of the song.
name: LowestNote

description: The final tone falls within the lower half of the total range.
name: LowerHalf

description: The final tone is located at or near the midpoint of the total range.
name: Midpoint

description: The final tone falls within the upper half of the total range.
name: UpperHalf

description: The final tone is the highest note of the song.
name: HighestNote

description: A monotone to a major second.
name: MonotoneMajorSecond

description: A minor third to a perfect fifth.
name: MinorThirdPerfectFifth

description: A minor sixth to an octave.
name: MinorSixthOctave

description: A minor ninth to a major fourteenth.
name: MinorNinthMajorFourteenth

description: Two octaves or more.
name: TwoOctavesOrMore

description: Monotone. No intervals occur. The song remains on approximately one pitch. A polyphonic song would be coded “monotone” if each part stays at the same pitch level.
name: Monotone

description: Narrow intervals. Intervals of a half step or less are prominent (though not necessarily predominant) in the song.
name: NarrowIntervals

description: Diatonic intervals. Diatonic melodies where whole step predominates.
name: DiatonicIntervals

description: Large intervals. Intervals of a third occur more frequently than other intervals.
name: LargeIntervals

description: Very large intervals. Intervals of a fourth and a fifth or larger predominate.
name: VeryLargeIntervals

description: No polyphony.
name: NoPolyphony

description: Drone polyphony. One or more tones are held or repeated while the melody follows its own course. The drone part or parts need not necessarily remain on the same level throughout the song. The pitch of the drone can be shifted, while another part moves freely around it. Do not code drone polyphony when the drone effect is only a transitory one.
name: DronePolyphony

description: Isolated chords. Chords occurring in a texture that is basically unison—chords that appear in a song otherwise sung in unison. Two different chords rarely succeed one another. In some cases, there may be only one chord in each section. If this chord tends to recur at the same point in each repetition, the song is coded 6. If not, the song is not considered polyphonic.
name: IsolateChords

description: Parallel chords. Two or more parts moving parallel to one another at pitch intervals other than the octave or unison. Parallel means that the parts move in the same direction. The distance between the parts does not have to be maintained at exactly the same interval throughout, as long as the general movement is parallel.
name: ParallelChords

description: Harmony. Contrary motion occurs. Some parts move downward while others move upward. This may also happen within the general context of parallel movement. As long as there is some significant amount of contrary motion, 10 can be coded.
name: Harmony

description: Counterpoint. Two or more parts that are rhythmically and melodically independent. In all other cases except drone polyphony, the parts move together rhythmically. In counterpoint, as distinct from the drone, the parts are active melodically. 13 is coded when at least two parts are rhythmically active and contrastive.
name: Counterpoint

description: Extreme embellishment.
name: ExtremeEmbeillishment

description: Much embellishment.
name: MuchEmbeillishment

description: Medium or considerable embellishment.
name: MediumEmbellishment

description: Slight embellishment.
name: SlightEmbellishment

description: Little or no embellishment.
name: LittleOrNoEmbellishment

description: Very slow.
name: VerySlow

description: Quite slow.
name: QuiteSlow

description: Slow
name: Slow

description: Moderate tempo.
name: ModerateTempo

description: Fast.
name: Fast

description: Very fast.
name: VeryFast

description: Very soft.
name: VerySoft

description: Soft
name: Soft

description: Mid-volume.
name: MidVolume

description: Loud
name: Loud

description: Very loud.
name: VeryLoud

description: Extreme rubato. If there is no beat, and the piece has already been coded 13 (Free rhythm) on Line 11 (Overall vocal rhythm), 1 is automatically coded.
name: ExtremeRubato

description: Much rubato.
name: MuchRubato

description: Some rubato. A small amount of freedom—for example, if pauses of irregular length occur between sections or stanzas of the melody.
name: SomeRubato

description: No rubato. Strict conformity to the beat.
name: NoRubato

description: Extreme rubato.
name: ExtremeRubato

description: Much rubato.
name: MuchRubato

description: Some rubato.
name: SomeRubato

description: No rubato.
name: NoRubato

description: Maximal glissando. Glissando is extremely prominent.
name: MaximalGlissando

description: Prominent glissando.
name: ProminentGlissando

description: Some glissando.
name: SomeGlissando

description: Little or no glissando.
name: LittleOrNoGlissando

description: Much melisma. Most of the pitch changes are unarticulated.
name: MuchMelisma

description: Some melisma. Some of the pitch changes are unarticulated.
name: SomeMelisma

description: Little or no melisma. Syllabic: All of the pitch changes are articulated in separate syllables.
name: LittleOrNoMelisma

description: Much tremolo. Tremolo is heavy throughout the song.
name: MuchTremolo

description: Moderate tremolo.
name: ModerateTremolo.

description: Some tremolo. Tremolo is present and noticeable, but relatively slight.
name: SomeTremolo

description: Slight tremolo.
name: SlightTremolo

description: Little or no tremolo
name: LittleTremolo

description: Much glottal. Strongly characterized by glottal activity.
name: MuchGlottal

description: Some glottal. Glottal activity present and noticeable.
name: SomeGlottal

description: Little or no glottal. Little or no glottal activity.
name: LittleOrNoGlottal

description: Very high. Usually falsetto in men.
name: VeryHigh

description: High. Usually head register.
name: HighestNote

description: Mid-voice.
name: MidVoice

description: Low. Usually sung “in the chest.”
name: Low

description: Very low. The singer is probably producing their lowest tone.
name: VeryLow

description: Very narrow. The narrowest, squeezed, thin, and tense voices. The vocal cavities are narrowed and constricted by raising the glottis, raising the tongue and pulling it back, and tensing the muscles in the throat.
name: VeryNarrow

description: Narrow. A markedly squeezed, narrow, and tense voice.
name: Narrow

description: Speaking. Medium width, neither narrow and tense nor wide and relaxed, this voice often has a speech-like quality.
name: Speaking

description: Wide. A relaxed, open-throated voice, usually evincing a considerable amount of resonance. This latter quality can be obscured by nasalization, which can be produced simultaneously.
name: Wide

description: Very wide. A wide-open, resonant, often ringing or liquid voice
name: VeryWide

description: Yodel. A distinctively liquid, wide-open, extremely relaxed way of singing. It is often, but not necessarily, characterized by quick, wide, and seemingly effortless leaps in pitch that pass from chesty tone to falsetto, or head tone, and back again.
name: Yodel

description: Extreme nasalization. Strongly nasalized throughout the performance.
name: ExtremeNasalization

description: Marked nasalization. Marked nasalization, with definite but not extreme nasality running throughout the performance.
name: MarkedNasalization

description: Intermittent nasalization. Nasality that occurs irregularly but clearly in the voice, as is frequently the case with singers of sub-Saharan African origin. This is the midpoint in the line and may be coded for songs that seem to be neither marked nor slight in their degree of nasality.
name: IntermittentNasalization

description: Slight nasalization. Occasional touches of nasalization that do not occur in relationship to nasal consonants. This situation is encountered, for example, in the singing of many groups of Central Europe.
Little or no nasalization. Where nasalization occurs only in connection with nasal consonants, or where nasal consonants tend to be eliminated and little or no nasalization is heard.
name: LittleOrNoNasalization

description: Extreme rasp. A markedly strident, hoarse, or grating singing voice.
name: ExtremeRasp

description: Great rasp. Pronounced rasp, but less strident than above.
name: GreatRasp

description: Intermittent rasp. Intermittent, or moderate and steady rasp.
name: IntermittentRasp

description: Slight rasp. Perceptible touches of rasp.
name: SlightRasp

description: None. Voices lack rasp.
name: None

description: Very forceful accent, with powerful stresses falling on many notes.
name: VeryForcefulAccent

description: Forceful accent, with strong accents falling on the main pulses of the meter.
name: ForcefulAccent

description: Moderate accent, a moderate stress falling along the main beat pattern of the meter, clearly outlining but not exaggerating it.
name: ModerateAccent

description: Relaxed accent, a relaxed handling of the accent pattern.
name: RelaxedAccent

description: Very relaxed, absence of clear stresses, such that a flowing, sometimes understated, melodic line is produced.
name: VeryRelaxed

description: Very precise enunciation. Highly articulated consonants and syllables. This is generally typical of the storytelling singers of Eurasian polities.
name: VeryPreciseEnunciation

description: Precise enunciation. Clearly articulated consonants in sung texts. Here one listens to the whole consonantal range and makes certain that all consonants are easily discernible.
name: PreciseEnunciation

description: Moderate enunciation. A moderate degree of enunciation.
name: ModerateEnunciation

description: Softened enunciation. Consonants are hard to distinguish and syllables are run together to some degree.
name: SoftenedEnunciation

description: Very softened enunciation. Situations in which consonants are absent or nearly absent from the text, and/or in which syllables are run together.
name: VerySoftenedEnunciation
